The present state of the art and outlooks E.A. Mamedov *, V. Cortds Corberfin lnstituto de Catalisis y Petroleoquimica, C.S.I.C., Campus U.A.M. -- Cantoblanco, 28049 Madrid, Spain Received 5 December 1994; accepted 23 February 1995 Abstract This review summarizes published data on catalytic performances of different vanadium-containing oxides, including unsupported and supported V205, vanadates, solid solutions and mixed phases, in the oxidative dehydrogenation of C2-C5 alkanes. The analysis of the structure-activity relationships shows that various species characterized by a different reactivity exist on the surface of these catalysts. There are some indications that tetrahedral vanadium species are the most favourable for alkane oxidehydrogenation. Its intrinsic activity seems to be largely dependent on the structure of the nearest surrounding and, therefore, can be modified by changing the nature and number of the neighbouring ions. Although the reaction mechanism is generally accepted to be through the redox cycle between V5 + and V4 +, opposite relationships between catalyst activity/selectivity and reducibility have been established, even for the same catalytic systems. No clear interpretation regarding the mode of alkane activation can be derived from a survey of the literature. This and some other aspects of the reaction mechanism need further studies at a molecular level. Keywords: Active site; Alkane; Mechanism; Oxidative dehydrogenation; Structure; Vanadium oxide 1. Introduction The dehydrogenation reactions could be used by industry for the production of propene, butene, butadiene, isobutene and isoprene from the corresponding alkanes. All these reactions are reversible due to the hydrogen evolved, and the alkane conversion is limited by thermodynamic equilibrium. In order to shift it towards the formation of the dehydrogenation products, the reactions are carried out at relatively high temperatures (from 820 to 920 K). At these temperatures, however, cracking of hydrocarbons occurs, reducing the selectivity of the reaction. The coke deposition causes a decrease in catalyst activity and the need for frequent regen- eration. One more difficult technological problem to be solved is the necessity to provide heat at high temperatures, which usually makes the process energy and capital intensive. Many of these obstacles can be overcome by providing the heat necessary for the reaction via 'in situ' oxidation of the hydrogen evolved as a product of pure dehydrogenation, or by operating with the stoichiometric oxidant in the presence of a catalyst capable of transforming the reaction into an oxidation [ 1-3]. The reaction, therefore, becomes exothermic and able to proceed at much lower tem- peratures at which the formation of carbon and cracking products is insignificant. A further advantage is that the conversion is no longer limited by thermodynamic factors. As oxidizing agents, molecular oxygen, nitrous oxides, halogens, elemental sulphur or its compounds, and others can be used. The most attractive reactant for industrial purposes seems to be molecular oxygen because of its low cost and less severe environmental impacts. According to Alkhazov and Lisovskii [2], dioxygen may perform different functions during the dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons. The first one is facilitating the pure dehydrogenation reaction by converting molecular hydrogen to water and shifting in this way the equilibrium towards the formation of dehydrogenated hydrocarbons. This feature may serve as a good evidence in favour of the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. In the presence of dioxygen, other oxidation reactions, such as partial oxidation to aldehydes or acids and combustion to carbon dioxide, usually occur, reducing the selectivity to dehydrogenation. The total oxidation is the most undesirable reaction. To diminish it, a periodic operation of the reactor using the metal oxide as oxygen transfer agent has been proposed [4]. In this mode of reaction, the metal oxide is first contacted with hydrocarbon (steam is often added to the feed), resulting in oxidative dehydrogenation of hydrocarbon and partial reduction of the metal oxide; the reduced metal oxide is then converted into a fully oxidized state by treatment with oxygen: CnHzn + 2 q- MxOy --~ CnH2~ q- H20 nt- MxOy- 1 MxOy- 1 + 0.502 --* MxOy This reaction strategy indeed can provide higher selectivity in comparison with the conventional method where hydrocarbon and oxygen are simultaneously in contact with an oxidation catalyst. The disadvantages are a more complicated technology and the need to develop a physically and chemically stable catalyst that can readily undergo continuous reduction-oxidation cycles. From our point of view, such a reaction with periodic operation should be considered to be noncatalytic because it is conducted using the metal oxide as a stoichiometric reactant, providing lattice oxygen which is depleted during reaction. So, a continuous, catalyst-mediated oxidative dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons using oxygen as the oxidizing agent appears to be more promising versus simple dehydrogenation. It enables one to achieve total conversion at much lower temper- atures. The main limitation is the formation of by-products, not always of economic interest. The oxidehydrogenation of alkanes produces usually a considerable amount of carbon oxides because of the low selectivity of the catalysts employed. The key aspect of the technology is, therefore, the development of catalysts capable of activating only the C-H bonds of the alkane molecule in a flow of oxygen. This 4 E.A. Mamedov, V. Cortes Corbercin/Applied Catalysis A: General 127 (1995) 1~40 problem becomes of global importance in light of the petrochemical industry's tendency to be based in the future on the direct use of alkanes as raw materials instead of alkenes [5,6]. The above-reported considerations intensified during the last decade the research in the direction of developing and studying catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes. During this time, a wide variety of catalytic systems, ranging from Li/MgO-like superbasic oxides [7,8] to highly acidic zeolites [9,10], have been proposed. Many of them are vanadium mixed oxides whereas effective catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of alkenes are based on molybdates [ 11 ], ferrites [12] or antimonates [ 13]. Besides, a number of investigations relating catalyst structure to catalytic activity and selectivity, and comparing one system with another, have appeared in the literature. There are also papers showing the catalyst phase composition or/and structure to be controlled to a large degree by the prep- aration method. For supported catalysts, the nature of the support becomes one more variable in determining the final catalytic properties. Several reviews have discussed oxidation catalysts containing vanadium [ 14- 18], but none is specifically concerned with oxidehydrogenation reactions. The objective of this paper is to screen the present state of the art in developing and studying catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of low-weight alkanes by analyz- ing the literature data published recently. The focus is placed on the vanadium- containing oxides which are currently being extensively studied as catalysts for these reactions. The approach used in the review is to examine the catalyst systems according to the complexity of the chemical composition. In summary, the nature of active sites and some aspects of the reaction network and mechanism are dis- cussed within the context of the catalyst design. 3. Vanadium pentoxide Vanadium(V) oxide is a well-established catalyst for the partial oxidation of hydrocarbons to oxygenated products [ 14-17]. Its catalytic behaviour is usually modified when deposited on a support with new surface structures. The most profound changes are frequently observed at low vanadium loadings not exceeding a monolayer. Species in the monolayer display higher activity and/or selectivity than the bulk V2Os, in a number of oxidation reactions [ 18 ]. Similar results have been obtained recently for oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes. 3.1. Its high surface area is expected to enable a high dispersion. It turns out from these studies that at low loadings, vanadia exists in a form of highly dispersed VOx monomeric units. There have been several studies on alkane oxidative dehydrogenation using silica-supported vanadia catalysts [ 19,22,37-41 ]. Only few have investigated the effects of loading and structure. The data on catalytic activity and selectivity reported in these papers are summarized in Fig. 1 as a function of the extent of silica coverage with a vanadia layer. Theoretical monolayer coverages have been calculated from the surface area occupied by one single V205 molecule (0.201 nm2) [ 29 ]. One can see that within the range of data obtained for different reactions, the overall activity per gram of vanadium shows a tendency to decrease with increasing vanadia loadings. There is a good agreement in the selectivity trends obtained by Le Bars et al. for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane [41 ] and by Owens and Kung for that of butane [22]. In both reactions, the lower loading samples display essentially higher selectivity to alkenes than the bulk V205. Fur- thermore, the decrease in selectivity as the conversion increases occurs much more slowly on these than on the higher loading samples, indicating that secondary reactions run faster on the latter. The differences in dehydrogenation selectivity have been found to correlate with the different vanadia structures present in silica- supported catalysts [ 22 ]. Laser Raman spectra of low-loading samples (up to 0.02 monolayer coverages) showed that only a well-dispersed vanadia species existed on their surface, while crystalline V205 was also formed on the higher loading samples (0.22-0.31 monolayer coverages). As the V205 species were suggested to contribute to the production of carbon oxides, better dehydrogenation selectivity on the low-loading samples was attributed to the presence of well-dispersed vana- dia. This was proposed to be a vanadyl group bonded to three oxygen ions of the support as follows: E.A. Mamedov, V. When in contact with ambient air, VOx species can react with atmospheric moisture giving a hydrated form. The evidence for acidic hydroxyl groups reported in ref. [41] could be related to the hydrated forms. The wideline 51V NMR lineshapes obtained for vanadia on silica under ambient (surface hydrated) conditions closely resemble those observed for bulk crystalline V205 [33]. Upon heating in a dry atmosphere, dehydration to a simple vanadyl species with the structure shown above may occur. As for the acidic character of silica-supported VOx monolayers, they have been regarded [41] as medium acidic materials containing both Lewis and BrOnsted acid sites of similar strength. An increase in their acidity enhances the rates of ethane total conversion and oxidative dehydrogenation but does not affect the selectivity to ethene. Owens and Kung [22] have emphasized the role of redox properties of the vanadium in determining the observed selectivity. In particular, the ease of oxygen removal from the lattice and the number of available lattice oxygen ions at the active site have been claimed to be the determining factor. The results of temper- ature-programmed reduction reported in refs. [36,40] show that silica-supported samples with dispersed vanadia undergo the reduction by hydrogen and ethane more easily than bulk V205 and silica-supported samples which contain crystalline V205. The increased oxygen mobility of the isolated vanadia species can explain their higher total activity but not the higher dehydrogenation selectivity. It appears that there is one more factor which plays an important role in determining the dehydrogenation selectivity. This may be a type of vanadium-oxygen bond that is involved in the rate-limiting step. One can expect that the activation of an alkane molecule by nucleophilic bridging oxygen will occur through a mechanism different from that involving more electrophilic double-bonded oxygen. Consequently, dif- ferent adsorbed intermediates and reaction products from them will be formed, but no experimental data, relating to this question, have been reported so far. A com- bined use of IR, XPS and EXAFS techniques could throw some light on this point. At variance with the above results, Oyama and Somorjai [ 19] have found that the oxidation of ethane to ethene occurs with high selectivity on high-loading vanadium oxide on silica while the lower loading samples display the same selec- tivity as the unsupported V205 does. Nevertheless, the results of catalyst charac- terization are in excellent agreement with those discussed above. Using laser Raman spectroscopy, Oyama et al. [28 ] have arrived at the conclusion that at low loadings (0.03 and 0.19 monolayer coverages), the vanadium oxide species is molecular, consisting of monomeric V=O units anchored to the silica surface. At higher loadings (0.43 to 1.14 monolayer coverages), it nucleates into small V205 crys- tallites, of size < 4 nm, but identical to bulk vanadium pentoxide. The considerable 8 E.A. Mamedov, V. This topic is discussed in detail in the Summary. Here we would like to propose an alternate explanation for the discrep- ancy between the selectivity trends of silica-supported vanadia reported in refs. [22,41], on the one hand, and in ref. [19], on the other. As far as there were no differences in the structure of the catalysts under comparison, the reason might be in the conditions of testing catalytic activity. The data presented in Fig. 1 were obtained at close temperatures (from 793 to 813 K) but with different reaction mixtures. Oyama and Somorjai [ 19] used a reaction mixture which contained a rather high (10 kPa) partial pressure of steam. Moreover, before every run the catalysts were pretreated in a flow of an O2-HzO-He mixture at the reaction temperature. The presence of large amounts of water vapour in the gas phase might impede the desorption of water molecules at octahedrally coordinated vanadium centres, thus preventing them from transformation into tetrahedrally coordinated ones. Such a change in the coordination number was observed in the absence of steam on isolated vanadyls but not on bulk vanadium pentoxide. If one assumes that this phenomenon contributes to the enhancement of dehydrogenation selectiv- ity on well-dispersed vanadia, an assumption advanced in ref. [41 ], then it becomes clear why the selectivity of low-loading catalysts in the presence of water does not differ from that of unsupported V205. The effect of water on the structure of VOx species has been discussed earlier in refs. [ 18,26,33]. As has been suggested by Bond and Tahir [18], the hydrated form of the monolayer species may become dehydrated at the temperatures gen- erally used for catalysis. On the other hand, many of the reactions performed by these catalysts produce water which may hydrate VOx species. They have concluded that only in-situ measurements under reaction conditions can resolve this question. 3.3. Alumina-supported vanadia Alumina-supported vanadia has been the object of numerous structural investi- gations [ 18,26,43-51]. While differences do exist in the details in these reports due to the type of alumina used and its physical properties, the general picture is the same: vanadia forms highly dispersed, amorphous phases whose structure changes from isolated vanadia tetrahedra at low loadings to polyvanadate species at medium loadings. At high loadings, crystalline V205 appears in addition to the amorphous vanadia phases. Reaction studies show [52-54] that catalysts contain- ing multilayered vanadium structures display higher activity (per supported vana- dium ion) and/or higher selectivity to partial oxidation products than both the low-loading samples and bulk VzOs. Raman studies of the catalysts tested in the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane suggest [58] that in the higher loading sample with a near monolayer coverage, a larger fraction of vanadia was in a two-dimensional network, whereas in the lower loading sample there were more isolated VOx species. The differences in their activities and selectivities have been interpreted in terms of the binding strength of the lattice oxygen to the catalyst. By a combined use of pulse technique and calorimetry, it was shown [56] that in the lower loading sample, lattice oxygen was bound more strongly than in the higher loading catalyst. In this respect, an important question arises: What oxygen species in vanadate structures is involved in the dehydroge- nation? There are two hypotheses in the literature based on indirect observations. As they see it, the selectivity is primarily determined by the competition between two processes: C- H bond breaking and C-O bond formation. Oxygen ions bridging two easily reduc- ible vanadium ions are believed to form C-O bonds easily, which would lead to the formation of oxygen-containing molecules. Most of them are based on results of catalyst characterizations before and after the catalytic reaction. Concluding remarks The data discussed in this paper give evidence that VeOs-based catalysts exhibit a fairly high activity in oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes. Being by nature rather selective in these reactions, most of them accelerate, however, the oxidation of alkenes to carbon oxides, reducing the dehydrogenation selectivity. The chal- lenge is now to suppress the overoxidation of dehydrogenated products. This can be done by modifying the catalyst with an appropriate additive, or/and by feeding in the reaction mixture water vapour or another substance able to block the catalyst E.A. Mamedov, V. The selectivity can be enhanced also by using an oxidant with a lower oxidizing power than that of the dioxygen. In this respect, it is intriguing to explore a possibility of using carbon dioxide instead of oxygen. As has been proposed in ref. [ 136], the acidic character of carbon dioxide requires to employ catalysts with moderate basic properties. Magnesium vanadates and many other reviewed catalysts meet the case. Another important question is the stability of the catalytic activity but it has strangely enough been missed in most publications. So, there is still considerable room for further improvement in per- formances of even the best vanadium-containing catalysts. It is clear that an improvement in the catalytic behaviour of known catalysts as well as a design of new ones require further development of our fundamental knowledge of the vanadium oxide system. Present literature data may be considered preliminary, and thorough studies on a series of topics are thought to be carried out. Above all, a much deeper investigation of the reaction dynamic mechanism and the correlation with the nature of the surface is necessary. Particular attention should be focused on an in situ evolution of the active surface and on the influence of surface reconstructions on the competitive pathways of reaction. The studies of the role of structural disorder and structural modifications by doping or preparing catalysts, and their relationships with the catalytic behaviour are to be continued as well. Such studies can open new approaches to designing effective catalysts and controlling their performance.
